final_answer.precision_note: Three significant figures from Q, Faraday constant, and molar mass input data.

method: Find charge passed: Q = I t = 1.50 A × (30.0 min ×60 s min-1) = 1.50 × 1800 = 2700 C. Moles of electrons are n(e-) = Q/F = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol e-. At cathode, Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu so moles Cu formed are half of electron moles: n(Cu)=0.02798/2=0.01399 mol. Multiply by Mr(Cu)=63.55 g mol-1: m(Cu)=0.01399×63.55 = 0.890 g (to 3 s.f.).
checks: Electrolysis charge is modest, giving only a few hundredths of a mole metal deposited, so grams should be < 1 g.
Copper mass from n(Cu)=0.01399 mol and 63.55 g mol-1 gives about 0.890 g, consistent with expected order of magnitude.
